funder.name: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This study represents the first comprehensive molecular assessment of freshwater fishes and lampreys from<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>ermany. We analysed<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content>sequences for almost 80% of the species mentioned in the current<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>erman<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">R</jats:styled-content>ed<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>ist. In total, 1056<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcodes belonging to 92 species from all major drainages were used to (i) build a reliable<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcode reference library, (ii) test for phylogeographic patterns, (iii) check for the presence of barcode gaps between species and (iv) evaluate the performance of the barcode index number (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>) system, available on the<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>arcode of<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>ife Data Systems. For over 78% of all analysed species,<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcodes are a reliable means for identification, indicated by the presence of barcode gaps. An overlap between intra‐ and interspecific genetic distances was present in 19 species, six of which belong to the genus<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>oregonus</jats:italic>. The Neighbour‐Joining phenogram showed 60 nonoverlapping species clusters and three singleton species, which were related to 63 separate<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>numbers. Furthermore,<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>arbatula barbatula</jats:italic>,<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>eucaspius delineatus</jats:italic>,<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>hoxinus phoxinus</jats:italic>and<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>qualius cephalus</jats:italic>exhibited remarkable levels of cryptic diversity. In contrast, 11 clusters showed haplotype sharing, or low levels of divergence between species, hindering reliable identification. The analysis of our barcode library together with public data resulted in 89<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s, of which 56% showed taxonomic conflicts. Most of these conflicts were caused by the use of synonymies, inadequate taxonomy or misidentifications. Moreover, our study increased the number of potential alien species in<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">G</jats:styled-content>ermany from 14 to 21 and is therefore a valuable groundwork for further faunistic investigations.</jats:p>
title: Molecular diversity of<scp>G</scp>ermany's freshwater fishes and lampreys assessed by<scp>DNA</scp>barcoding
